summary.p: Yesterday, the decision of the Diet of Worms was read in the [Basel] council; undoubtedly, this will also be communicated to the [Zurichers]. For the new religious colloquy in Regensburg, four scholars, eight auditors, and two presidents are to be appointed by both the Papists and the [Evangelicals]. Whether some [Protestant princes] will invite to this is uncertain. - The Council of Trent has been postponed until the [Catholics] agree on at least some articles. Bullinger will get to see the proposals for agreement advocated by the Bucerans, Lutherans, and Papists [in the writing "Von den einigen rechten wegen... christlicher religion zu vergleichen"]. Gast would like to learn from Bucer and also from [Simon] Sulzer why they harbor such aversion against the Zurich church. More on that later.

div.p: The decisions made at the Diet of Worms were read yesterday in our council; without a doubt, they will also communicate them to you, as they have done so far. A new colloquy has been established in Regensburg concerning religious matters, and our side and the Papists will each appoint four scholars; then, each side will select eight auditors for this colloquy; thirdly, two presidents will be chosen to impose silence on the contentious. However, whether any of our churches will be invited to that colloquy, I do not know.

The Council of Trent has been postponed until they agree on at least some articles. You will see the plans of the Bucerans and Lutherans and the Papist agreements, etc. I want to bring Bucer, or rather Sulzer, and accompany him for one mile, to discuss with him why he is so unfair to the Zurich church. More on that later.
To Lord Heinrich Bullinger, his dearest brother. Zurich.
